results.notes:
Found underneath a dead log- tree unknown. Growing from pieces of broken off bark. I will include the only picture of the tree I took, and of “berries” from tree (to aid identifying the tree) will be included. No spores appear present, waiting on spore print in case there are any. Top of Caps are dark brown with a slightly moist velvety texture. Stems have striations and upon removal of one of the caps the stem appears to get slightly bigger towards the top and it is also hollow from the top where the cap was removed… upon looking down into the stem where the cap used to attach it is hollow with little micro hairs inside.
The gills don’t appear to be exactly alike- they stagger and vary in size. (Pardon any “incorrect” terminology, I am GREEN)

results.notes:
Found growing alone in ditch by the road, caramel colored cap, cream to pinkish colored gills, stem has small white fibers where it meets the gills, gills do not run onto stem, stem is brittle like psathyrella I’ve found in the same exact spot, this looks a little different from those, cap also has lines you can see in the pic, very cold here and very wet for days
Spore print is purple brown
Edit* it was a younger specimen that’s why it looked different from the first ones I found there, after taking the spore print the color of the cap turned white/cream colored. This is psathyrella im pretty sure, can some tell exactly what type though?

results.notes:
Habitat: Roadside dirt bank near oak tree, ground
Cap: 5 cm, plane, lilac and gray brown, smooth, dry, split margin; context white, no staining
Pore surface: white, not depressed at stalk, not immediately staining but next day was brown, 2-2.5 pores/mm, tube depth 6 mm
Stalk: 3 cm above ground, 2.5 cm below ground, 20 mm apex, 22 mm base at ground level, lilac, lilac reticulation at least halfway down, basal mycelium white; flesh white, no staining, center eaten out
Chemical reactions: on cap—KOH yellow orange, NH4OH and FeSO4 negative?; on context—KOH negative, NH4OH and FeSO4 negative; on stalk—KOH ochre, NH4OH negative
Odor and taste: taste bitter, odor not distinctive
Spore print: didn’t work

results.notes:
collected at an unknown location within the Bohemia Eco Preserve in Sonoma County. The spores are amyloid, about 10µ x 7µ.
I’m suggesting the name Porpoloma because it looks like a Tricholoma to me and the spores are amyloid.
It has a strongly farinaceous odor. Not unpleasant.
No bruising reactions.
Unfortunate that lower ends of stems were not well-collected.
a drop of KOH on the cap shows a very faint yellowing.

results.notes:

Chemical reactions: on cap—KOH orange, NH4OH amber, FeSO4 dark green; cap context—KOH orange, NH4OH negative, FeSO4 blue green

Same as PRM-1951 but younger

results.notes:
Squamules with green upper surface and whitish lower surface (due to sort of reticulate-looking white fibers). Squamules often curled over when dry, exposing lower surface. Large white grains (soredia? soralia?) on lower surface of squamules. Larger squamules approaching 1cm diam. Podetia: covered in coarse soredia inside cup and along sides. Apothecia observed on one podetium, tiny, brown, along rim of podetium cup. Upper surfaces of some lobe tips densely white-pruinose.

Thallus P+ orange, yellowish-orange on lower surface (update: slowly became oranger) becoming darker orange toward squamule tips. Squamule K+Y in section and also when K applied directly to lobes (underside and lobe tip). Podetia UV+ blue-white underneath layer of soredia.

Growing among moss on sandy soil.

results.notes:
Bandini, Ditte, Bernd Oertel, Sebastian Ploch, Tahir Ali, Jukka Vauras, Anja Schneider, Markus Scholler, Ursula Eberhardt, and Marco Thines. “Revision of some central European species of Inocybe (Fr.: Fr.) Fr. subgenus Inocybe, with the description of five new species.” Mycological Progress 18, no. 1 (2019): 247-294.
Page 264:
“Apparently, the species has also been
found in Canada, British Columbia, on the Queen Charlotte
Islands archipelago (GenBank HQ604526, F19796; UBC
Herbarium, online), labelled I. auricoma. The climate of
these islands is oceanic with cool summers and mild winters.
On the specimen label of UBC (F19796) it is noted: wet
hypermaritime. The only basidioma has been found with
Western Hemlock (Tsuga heterophylla).”
…
“In the UBC Herbarium of the University of British
Columbia, Vancouver, Canada, a specimen is deposited
(F19796), the ITS of which is identical with the sequences
from the Austrian collections. The photograph of the only
basidioma shows the typical
strongly conical habit, yellow colour and smooth surface
of pileus. The stipe is widened towards the base, but the
base itself has not been preserved. The size of spores is
indicated with 8–10 × 5–5.5 (6.0) μm, which lies in the
range of those of Inocybe venustissima. The shape of the
roughly pencil-drawn two cystidia can be observed in I. venustissima too. Oluna Ceska has noted that the stipe
is not pruinose and the species has been determined as
I. auricoma —probably due to the fact that the bulb is
missing. The base of the stipe of I. auricoma is not bulbous at all and the basidiomata are smaller than those of
I. venustissima (see Batsch 1783; Lange 1917; Kuyper
1986; Kuyper and Weholt 1988).”

results.notes:
Ascobolus crenulatus – # 50692
Récolté par Jules Cimon

Date de récolte: 2017.10.17
Substrat : excréments de chien
Apothécie jusqu’à 1,5 mm de diam., à marge distincte
Hyménophore jaune ochracé faiblement olivâtre à pourpre brunâtre, brun foncé faiblement olivâtre au sec
Face externe furfuracée, jaune ochracé à brunâtre
Spores ellipsoïdes, finement verruqueuses au début, avec stries longitudinales subparallè-les, parfois anastomosées, gris brunâtre à gris pourpré, 10,8-12,3 × 5,7-7,9 µm, 11,4 × 6,5 µm en moyenne, Q = 1,8
Asques cylindriques à moyennement ventrus à maturité, operculés, à 8 spores bisériées, avec crochet à la base et appareil apical inamyloïde, à contenu parfois légèrement dextri-noïde, 96,3-143,2 × 9,3-13,2 µm
Paraphyses filiformes à étroitement cylindriques, ramifiées à la base, souvent un peu élar-gies et parfois effilées-obtuses vers l’apex, septées, à contenu huileux guttulé (?) sur toute la longueur, jusqu’à 130 × 6,5 µm
Hyménium olivâtre dans H2O au microscope
Excipulum en textura globulosa, faiblement teinté de pourpre
Remarque :
L’apex des asques et paraphyses est enduit d’une substance gélifiée jaunâtre finement incrustée, persistant sur les paraphyses à maturité.
Identification: J. Cimon
Étude microscopique: J. Labrecque
Recherche et confirmation d’identification: R. Labbé
Texte: J. Labrecque

results.notes:
Belonioscyphella pluriseptata – 50713

Récolté par J. Cimon
Substrat : sur mousse vivante d’un terrain moussu humide
Apothécie jusqu’à 0,5 de diam. × 0,4 µm de hauteur totale
Hyménophore lisse, blanc
Asques clavés, longuement graduellement pédicellés, à 8 spores bisériées, avec crochet à la base et appareil apical amyloïde, jusqu’à 176 × 19,4 µm
Paraphyses cylindriques, progressivement élargies de la base à l’apex un peu renflé, non ramifiés, parfois anastomosées à la base, avec 2-3 septa, à contenu huileux hyalin/jaunâtre environ 100%, finement nuageux(?), jusqu’à 143,2 × 3,8 µm, dépassant les asques de 5-8 µm
Spores fusoïdes, légèrement arquées à rarement anguleuses sur la partie médiane, hyalines, germant aux 2 extrémités, avec 7 septa, rarement 8, (33,9)37,3-50(50,4) x (5,8)5,9-7(7,5) µm, 43,6 × 6,6 µm en moyenne, Q = (5,4)5,5-8,1(8,5), Q moyen = 6,7
Excipulum ectal en textura prismatica ascendant
Poils marginaux cylindriques, à cellules progressivement renflées vers la base, septés, avec apex obtus et légèrement enduit d’une substance gélatineuse hyaline, jusqu’à 72,4 × 3,2 µm
N.B. Tout l’ascome est hyalin sans coloration au microscope

Identification: Ascofrance (Zuzana Egertova)
Recherche et révision de texte: R. Labbé
Étude microscopique et microphotographie: J. Labrecque

results.notes: This sample was found in association with various other fruiting bodies emerging from the remains of a single decaying hardwood tree at the edge of the park. Attached are images showing the various fruiting bodies emerging from this single tree. I initially identified the species as Ganoderma applanatum (Artist’s Bracket), but was unaware of the species displaying the layered phenotype shown in the more mature fruiting bodies on the decaying tree. After additional research online, I believe the species to be Ganoderma lobatum due to the phenotype of the fruiting bodies, substrate, and visual similarity to other reference images on iNaturalist.

Calycina subherbarum

Récolteur : Jules Cimon
Date de récolte: 2008.10.25
Habitat: terrain vague
Hôte: tige de plante de plate-bande, éricacée probable

Spores fusoïdes, légèrement arquées, à un septum, lisses, hyalines, guttulées, avec 1 grosse guttule de chaque côté du septum et une moyenne à chaque pôle et parfois quelques petites entre les grosses, 12-17 × 2-3 µm, 14,1 × 2,5 µm en moyenne (10 spores), Q = 5,64
Asques à 8 spores bisériés, avec appareil apical amyloïde, 90-105 × 5-7 µm. Crochets présents à la base
Paraphyses cylindriques, rarement lancéolées, parfois légèrement élargies à l’apex, non ramifiées, à 3-6 septa, avec quelques petites guttules sur la moitié inférieure, hyalines, 100-110 × 2-4 µm
Excipulum ectal en textura angularis, à cellules terminales polymorphes, caténulées, subglobuleuses, clavées, cylindriques, lancéolées, élargies ou déformées à l’apex, ou cystidioïdes-fusoïdes, à paroi épaisse à mince, ochracées en NaCl iso., grises en Melzer
Poils banaux, cylindriques, à paroi mince
Sporée non disponible
Recherche et supervision: R. Labbé
Collaborateur: Hans O. Baral
Texte: J. Labrecque

results.notes:
Habitat: Former pasture partly overgrown with tall herb, bushes and scattered trees; slightly inclined terrain, southeast aspect; calcareous, skeletal, colluvial ground; open, sunny place; exposed to direct precipitations, average precipitation ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 600 m (1.970 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: bark of a dead trunk of Juglans regia in its initial disintegration stage laying on ground, partly sitting on Collema sp. (probably Collema crispum = Blennothallia crispa) thallus.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Habit and presence of lime crystals speak almost certainly in favor of the genus Didymium. Dimensions of spores inclined me toward Didymium melanospermum (Pers.) T. Macbr. at first. However, other traits, particularly furrowed stalks, whitish stalk color (should be dark to black) and presence of lime in them (it should be absent), changed my initial supposition in favor to similar Didymium squamulosum (Alb. & Schwein.) Fr. in spite of the fact that measured spore dimensions doesn’t fit so nicely to the second option. Another discrepancy of the find (related to booth species) is the fact that vast majority of the sporocarps appeared sessile, while they should normally be distinctly stalked and only rarely ‘sessile’. According to literature Didymium squamulosum is considered a very variable species and apparently sessile sporocarps are found occasionally too, so they may not be a severe argument against this determination.

Description: Sporocarps up to 1.1 mm tall, most of them seemingly sessile having rudimentary stalks hidden in strongly umbicilate sporocysts below; only a few distinctly stalked; sporocysts sub-globose or oblate, 0.6-1 mm in diameter, when wet bluish-gray, half dry pale-gray, when dry white; with simple, membranous, colorless to light-yellowish, translucent peridium covered by a thick layer of crystalline lime; crystals usually larger than spores; (hypo)columella present, flattened, perimeter about 1/3 or slightly less of the sporocysts perimeter; white to beige, light brownish (best seen in transparent light); capillitium thin, scantily branched with rare, small nodular swellings; attached to peridium. Stalks short, mostly hidden; some distinct but not longer than 2/3 of sporocysts diameter, longitudinally striate, No confluent plasmodial form observed at the site of stalk attachment to substrate.

Camera:
AmScope MA500 digital camera on Olympus CH20; pictures: 1M, 3M, 4M, 5M. 6M and 12M.
Sony ILCE6000 on trinocular stereomicroscope Novex RZ, Holland; pictures: 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 7M, 8M, 9M, 10M and 11M.
Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8; pictures: 1, 2, 3 and 4.
results.location_name: Lower Trenta Valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia
